titlestmt.titleproper: Preliminary Guide to the Kiev Foundation graphics arts and artifacts collection, 1493-1969 K0005
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 14:11:55 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.unittitle: Kiev Foundation Graphics Arts and Artifacts Collection
did.abstract: The collection includes prints, posters, cartoons, one Yellow Star of David Badge, postcards and other Judaica, much of it related to antisemitism.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Kiev Foundation graphics arts and artifacts collection, Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The graphic arts collection is an artificial collection of materials donated primarily by the Kiev Foundation after the original donation of the I. Edward Kiev Judaica Collection in 1996.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The graphic arts and artifacts collection in an artificial collection of materials donated primarily by the Kiev Family Trust after the original donation of the I. Edward Kiev Judaica Collection in 1996.
This is an open collection and materials continue to be acquired.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection includes prints, posters, one Yellow Star of David Badge, cartoons, postcards and other Judaica, much of it related to antisemitism.
Recent acquisitions include the purchase of 30 original postcards from artist E. M. Lilien.

arrangement.head: Collection Organization
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: Jewish art, antisemitica, and miscellaneous artifacts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of graphic materials which were purchased after the donation of the original collection by the estate of I. Edward Kiev. There are roughly ninety items, which date from about 1910 to 1920. One box contains postcards depicting the work of Ephraim Mose Lilien, a Zionist iconographer and prominent contributor to the Art Nouveau movement. The other contains lithographs by the artist Hermann Struck, from the book, "Das Osjische Antlitz" [The Face of Eastern European Jewry], published in 1920. Both Lilien and Struck contributed works to an art exhibition held at the Fifth Zionist Congress in 1901, which helped establish Jewish visual art as a legitimate component of the Jewish cultural resurgence.

did.unittitle: A Jewish Woman with her Veil and Rich Ornaments

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Copper plate engraving taken from the first English-language edition of Augustin Calmet's Dictionnaire historique, critique, chronologique, géographique et littéral de la Bible, originally published in Paris (1722). Subsequent English-language editions contained a different set of plates. This engraving was meant to accompany the entry for "Veil".

Augustin Calmet. An historical, critical, geographical, chronological, and etymological dictionary of the Holy Bible, in three volumes. Samuel D'Oyly and John Colson, translators. London : Printed for J.J. and P. Knapton, D. Midwinter and A. Ward, A. Bettesworth and C. Hitch, J. Pemberton, J. Osborn and T. Longman, C. Rivington, F. Clay [and 3 others in London], 1732.

Augustin Calmet. An historical, critical, geographical, chronological, and etymological dictionary of the Holy Bible, in three volumes. Samuel D'Oyly and John Colson, translators. London : Printed for J.J. and P. Knapton, D. Midwinter and A. Ward, A. Bettesworth and C. Hitch, J. Pemberton, J. Osborn and T. Longman, C. Rivington, F. Clay [and 3 others in London], 1732.

Augustin Calmet. An historical, critical, geographical, chronological, and etymological dictionary of the Holy Bible, in three volumes. Samuel D'Oyly and John Colson, translators. London : Printed for J.J. and P. Knapton, D. Midwinter and A. Ward, A. Bettesworth and C. Hitch, J. Pemberton, J. Osborn and T. Longman, C. Rivington, F. Clay [and 3 others in London], 1732.

did.unittitle: Two leaves from an early English Bible

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Leaves are taken from Deuteronomy; 11" x 16"

did.unittitle: Leaf from an early English Bible

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This leaf, which appears to have originated from a different edition than the two Deuteronomy leaves in this collection, includes "The Prayer of Menasseh King of the Iewes" and "A Very Profitable Declaration for the Understanding of the Histories of Ezra, Nehemiah, Ester, Daniel, and Diverse Other Places of Scripture". 10 3/4" x 15 3/4"

did.unittitle: Map of Asia Minor Showing the Land and Rivers of Eden and Illustrating the First Division of the Earth among the Sons of Noah

odd.p: Leaf taken from Biblical Natural Science: Being the Explanation of all References in Holy Scripture to Geology, Botany, Zoology, and Physical Geography by John Duns (London: William MacKenzie, [186-?]); 12 1/2" x 9 1/4"

A New Map of Palestine or the Holy Land

odd.head: General note
odd.p: From Mitchell's New General Atlas, Philadelphia: S. Augustus Mitchell, 1872.

did.unittitle: Pair of undated color prints bound together: "Die Haupt-Synagoge in Fürth erbaut im Jahre 1616", engraved by G. Löwensohn (1839); and "Synagoge, Innenraum"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Prints are adhered to matting boards enclosed within hard cloth-bound covers. The closed book measures 16" x 14.25" x 0.25"

did.unittitle: Genealogica Herodum, engraving by Jan Goeree (1670-1731)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Engraving published as a fold-out plate in Adriaan Reelant. Hadriani Relandi Palaestina ex monumentis veteribus illustrata. Trajecti Batavorum: Ex libraria Guilielmi Broedelet, 1714. 17 1/2" x 7 3/4".

odd.head: General
odd.p: Behar et Fils, publishers. Set of 12 postcards. 3.5" x 5.5" x 0.25".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains posters, woodcuts, a Yellow Star of David Badge, and cards ranging from 1493 to 1969 with the bulk of materials dating from about 1900 to 1950. Topically, they chronicle anti-Semitism from various periods of heightened persecution such as the Inquisition and Nazi Germany.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Hand-colored etching by William Heath. Published by T. McLean, London. An old clothes dealer and a Moroccan Jewish peddler at the door of the House of Commons.

did.unittitle: Jews at luncheon (or/ A peep into Dukes place)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Hand-colored etching by Thomas Rowlandson.

did.unittitle: King Jerry treating his Jewish subjects with Westphalia Venison

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Hand-colored etching. Published by Thomas Tegg. Print made by Charles Williams after George Moutard Woodward, London. Satire on the emancipation of the Jews of Westphalia by King Jerome. Also refers to supposed Jewish support of Napoleon.

did.unittitle: Humours of Houndsditch (or/ Mrs. Shevi in a longing condition)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Etching by Thomas Rowlandson. Published by Thomas Tegg, London. A Jew brings home a suckling pig.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Hand-colored etching by Isaac Cruikshank from an original by Woodward. Published by Allen & West, London. Scene in the Pump Room at Bath from Macklin's comedy 'The Man of the World'.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Leaf from Hartmann Schedel's, "Weltchronik," or, "Chronicle of the World," better known today as the "Nuremberg Chronicle", depicting the burning of the Jew Eleazar and his family.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Leaf from Hartmann Schedel's, "Weltchronik," or, "Chronicle of the World," better known today as the "Nuremberg Chronicle", depicting a ritual bloodletting.

did.unittitle: Finance in the USA is 98% in Jewish hands

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Shows Secretary of U.S. Treasury Henry Morgenthau.

did.unittitle: The media in the USA in 97% controlled by Jewish hands

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Shows a younger Adolph Ochs, editor of the New York Times.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Depicting crudely stereotyped Jew lurking behind the flags of the principal Allied Powers.

did.unittitle: Red Army soldier, Are you going to liberate other nations? First liberate yourself from your oppressors!

odd.head: General note
odd.p: An anti-Semitic poster with Russian text and caricatures. German issued propaganda encouraging the common soldier to rise up against the NKVD (Stalin's secret police), Stalin and ultimately the Jews.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Probably produced between 1930 and 1945. Produced by a medical student organization and probably aimed primarily at other students, the poster appears to be an attempt to draw on fears of Christian students in the medical fields that Jews were making inroads that would threaten the virtual monopoly on these fields by Christians. The PIF! of course, is the sound of an insecticide sprayer (note the "I" in PIF has a nozzle which is spraying poison on ;the Jewish caricatures). The phenomenon of Argentinean anti-Semitism is especially interesting, since Argentina itself was a Mecca for both Jewish settlement form the 1890s through the 1950s, as well as a haven for Nazis and proto-Nazis during the same period.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Housed with University Archive material in the first map case in FF1.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Accompanied by translations and photocopies of the original images.

did.unittitle: Thirty-three antisemitic cartoons from "Puck" and "Harper's Weekly" periodicals
Book of Graphics from Nazi Germany
Jen Drazme Se Povzdy Ceskeho Naroda

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The Jew holds a flag which satirizes and stereotypes the Jewish people. Elements include: the three balls of the pawn shop; old clothing (for tailoring), "Our Friend", the building fire; "Our Enemy", the fireman; et al.

did.unittitle: Russian Jews Caricatures of Three Jewish Women
The Little Cohen "Haven't You Seen The Little Cohen?"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Woman thumbs her nose at the Jew.

did.unittitle: Jewish Scottsman "Say, Kid! If That Aint Camouflage, Ask Me What Is!"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Caricature of a Scottish Jew

did.unittitle: Painted Jewish Caricatures: Jews Are Scratching Their Fleas

odd.head: General note
odd.p: "Levy's Publicity Stunt. A vulgar guest perfromance brought rich returns, but in the long run was too dangerous."

did.unittitle: Humorous Jewish Caricatures Jewish Merchants Consult

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Two "50 Pfennig" and two "Eine Mark" notes bearing the reproduced signature of "Der Aelteste der Juden in Litzmannstadt M. Rumkowski"

odd.head: General
odd.p: Found among possessions of Ms. Viola Paul, Vineland, N.J. A Jewish immigrant from Czechoslovakia, she was born in Sucany, a small town in the north of Slovakia and was probably in her late forties during WWII. Donated by Dr. Jan Simko, whose mother's brother was married to Ms. Paul.
No information identifying the owner of the Star of David exists .

odd.head: General note
odd.p: One "Zwei Mark" and one "Fuenf Mark" note bearing the reproduced signature of "Der Aelteste der Juden in Litzmannstadt M. Rumkowski"

did.unittitle: Directory of Jewish Refugees form (probably from Shanghai)

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Written in both English and Chinese or Japanese, this form records personal and immigration information pertaining to Charlotte Gruenberg, a Jewish dressmaker whose passport was issued in Vienna. A photograph is adhered to the form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While the other artifacts in this collection relate to the Holocaust or the Nazi era, and thus are assigned to Series 2: Anti-Semitica, Series 3: Miscellaneous Artifacts consists of items documenting other facets of Jewish life in America and Europe.

did.unittitle: Ticket for High Holiday synagogue seat

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Services held at Chevre Ets Heym Mahzike ha-Ra, 24 Snediker Avenue, Brooklyn, New York. The ticket lists Cantor Yoseph Narflus, Synagogue President Chaim Koppel Glik, and Vice President Ben-Zion Piken.
Ticket found in I. Edward Kiev Judaica Collection book donated by Walter Kurt Kahn, Professor Emeritus of Engineering and Applied Science at the George Washington University.

did.unittitle: Postcard of Traunstein von Ettendorf, Germany

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Postcard addressed to Fräulein Erna (illegible surname) in Wiesbaden. The handwritten message is very difficult to read but appears to include "greetings and kisses" from the recipient's brother, whose signature is illegible.

Postcard found in I. Edward Kiev Judaica Collection book (BM 675 .F45 A3 1864 v. 1) donated by Walter Kurt Kahn, Professor Emeritus of Engineering and Applied Science at the George Washington University.
